kunyomi.meaning: one thing

jukugo.word: もう一度 ( もういちど )
description: 一 (one) + 度 (times) = もう一度 (one more time!)

jukugo.word: 一緒 に ( いっしょ に)
description: 一 (one) + 緒 (together) = 一緒 (together)

jukugo.word: 一人 で ( ひとり で)
description: 一 (one) + 人 (person) = 一人 (one person, alone)

jukugo.word: 一般的 な ( いっぱんてき な)
jukugo.meaning: One of many many Japanese words for 'normal.' The nuance of いっぱんてき　is ordinary, non-special - as opposed to a member of a special group of people of things. 一般的な人 means, an average person. As in, 'an average person is not allowed in this Yakuza bar.'
description: 一般 (generally, commonly) + 的 (motivation / '-al') = 一般的 (ordinary)
一 (one) + 日 (sun, day) = 一日 (first day of the month)
一 (one) + 番 (number) = 一番 (number one!)

mnemonic: as in, "Vince NEIL has two chins."

kunyomi.meaning: two things

jukugo.word: 二人 で ( ふたり で)
description: 二 (two) + 人 (person) = 二人 (two people)
二 (two) + 月 (moon) = 二月 (February)

jukugo.word: 二日酔い ( ふつかよい )
description: 二 (two) + 日 (sun, day) + 酔 (drunk) = 二日酔い (hangover)
二 (two) + 日 (sun, day) = 二日 (second day of the month)

jukugo.word: XXX 二重 (XXX にじゅう )
jukugo.meaning: PREFIX meaning double, as in "double-chin" or "twin-engine plane." (PRE)
description: 二 (two) + 重 (heavy / overlap) = 二重 (double-xxx)

jukugo.word: 三人 で ( さんにん で)

三 (three) + 月 (moon) = 三月 (March)
三 (three) + 角 (horn/corner) = 三角 (triangle)

To me it just looks like a broken coat hanger, which is totally useless.

jukugo.word: 完了 する ( かんりょう する)
jukugo.meaning: to finish work on a project - an annual report, a re-formatting of the database, etc. (NP)
description: 完 (complete) + 了 (total) = 完了 (finish)

jukugo.meaning: roger that! ('I got it!') (originally used by military, but now often used when you text, because of its brevity)!
description: 了 (total) + 解 (solve / untie) = 了解 (OK, got it.)

kunyomi.meaning: child

description: 子 (child) + 供 (accompany) = 子供 (child)

jukugo.meaning: parents and child together - also the rather cruel name for a traditional dish: boiled chicken served with scrambled eggs. (KUNKUN, SARC)
description: 親 (parents/kindness) + 子 (child) = 親子 (meat and eggs)

jukugo.meaning: the condition something's in. Can be used with a living thing or object. Always used only with いい or 悪い. Usually emphaizes the LONG TERM condition. Although hungover people have been heard to remark, 調子が悪い！
description: 調 (check out) + 子 (child) = 調子 (condition)

jukugo.word: 車椅子 ( くるまいす )
description: 車 (car) + 子 (chair) = 車椅子 (wheelchair)

kunyomi.meaning: woman - but don't say it by itself, it's like saying 'That broad.'

jukugo.word: 女の子 ( おんなのこ )
jukugo.meaning: girl . Newspapers use it for a female up through junior high, but guys talking about 'chicks,dude' might use it to refer to a 20 year old.
description: 女 (woman) + 子 (child) = 女の子 (girl)

jukugo.meaning: her. Might also mean 'girlfriend' depending on context.
description: 彼 (him) + 女 (woman) = 彼女 (her / girlfriend)

jukugo.word: 女の人 ( おんなのひと )
jukugo.meaning: the polite- but not formal - way to say woman
description: 女 (woman) + 人 (person) = 女の人 (woman)
少 (a little (amount)) + 女 (woman) = 少女 (young girl)

jukugo.meaning: PREFIX used about women from first grade through college. Used to refer to female students as a group: "女子 line up on the left side of the class, 男子 (danshi) line up on the right side." BOOBOO: You wouldn't say "She's a joshi." (PRE)
description: 女 (woman) + 子 (child) = 女子 (female xxx / xxx for girls)

jukugo.meaning: female - emphasizes biology, (sex, rather than gender).
description: 女 (woman) + 性 (sex / essential nature) = 女性 (female)

jukugo.word: 女子高生 ( じょしこうせい )
description: 女子 (PREFIX used about women from first grade through college. Used to refer to female students as a group: "女子 line up on the left side of the class, 男子 (danshi) line up on the right side." BOOBOO: You wouldn't say "She's a joshi." ) + 高 (tall) + 生 (life / birth) = 女子高生 (high school girl.)

kunyomi.meaning: to like
To have a preference for.
The noun form of 好む. You often say, 'That's my konomi,' meaning 'That's my favorite kind' . . . but it also implies that you know a lot about that thing.(***)

description: 大 (big) + 好 (like) = 大好き (really like)

jukugo.meaning: literally, 'look' or 'shape,' as in 'He's dressed as a woman' : おんなの格好してる。
description: But　usually it means 'coolness:' かっこいい (cool) or かっこうわるい (not).(when used in the figurative, 'cool' sense, it is usually KANA) (1/2 KANA)
格 (character, aspect) + 好 (like) = 格好 (looks)

jukugo.word: 格好つける ( かっこうつける )
jukugo.meaning: this is a rad one. it means "try too hard to be cool". (Literally "manufacturing coolness") (KANA)
description: 格 (character, aspect) + 好 (like) = 格好つける (try too hard to be cool)

jukugo.word: 好奇心 ( こうきしん )
description: BOOBOO: if you want to say you're curious about a specific thing, you'd use 興味　（きょうみ） instead.
好奇心 usually means "curiosity-in-general": 　you have an inquiring personality, or a gaze of curiosity on your face. You'd never say, "Oh, you play in a band? 好奇心ある！”
好 (like) + 奇 (strange) + 心 (heart) = 好奇心 (curiosity)

mnemonic: Genghis KHAN raped three women.

jukugo.word: 強姦 する ( ごうかん する)

jukugo.word: 法定強姦 ( ほうていごうかん )
description: 法 (law) + 定 (plan) + 強姦 (rape) = 法定強姦 (statuatory rape)

jukugo.word: 近親相姦 ( きんしんそうかん )
description: 近 (near) + 親 (parents/kindness) + 相 (partner) + 姦 (rape) = 近親相姦 (incest)

kunyomi.meaning: mouth

description: 出 (pull out / hand over) + 口 (mouth) = 出口 (exit.)
入 (put/go in) + 口 (mouth) = 入り口 (entrance)
悪 (bad) + 口 (mouth) = 悪口 (talking shit about someone.)

jukugo.word: 銀行口座 ( ぎんこうこうざ )
description: 銀行 (bank) + 口 (mouth) + 座 (sit) = 銀行口座 (bank account)
人 (person) + 口 (mouth) = 人口 (population)

jukugo.meaning: the kind of depressing place where you get a ticket or food from a person in a box with usually a bulletproof plexiglas window between you and them. (KUNKUN)
description: 窓 (window) + 口 (mouth) = 窓口 (service window)
口 (mouth) + 説 (explain) = 口説く (pester)

作 (make) + 品 (products) = 作品 (artworks.)

jukugo.meaning: can be used of people or things. It means graceful or sophisticated in a quiet or understated way. When it comes to people, 上品 is usually used about women, I mean 'ladies.'

mnemonic: He used his mouth to say it 4 times already! If he says it AGAIN, I swear I'll stomp that ass.

kunyomi.meaning: to say

jukugo.meaning: ANY word - unlike the related term 単語（たんご）、　言葉 can refer to compound words, or onomonopoeia. Also 言葉 can mean "way of speaking." There are expressions like "watch what you say!" that use 言葉 this way: 言葉使い が丁寧 (her way of speaking is very polite!) or 言葉大切につかいましょう （let's be careful how we speak!) (FP)

助 (save) + 言 (say) = 助言 (advice)

jukugo.word: 言語の壁 ( げんごのかべ )
description: 言 (say) + 語 (language) + 壁 (wall) = 言語の壁 (the language barrier )

description: 言 (say) + 葉 (leaf) + 遣 (apply) = 言葉遣い (one's choice of words)

I lower it (1/2 KANA)
it gets lowered

below (下) + one stroke. You can think of 不運 (unlucky) or 不平等 (unfair) as being below or less than lucky or fair.

jukugo.meaning: a mystery or unexplainable thing. BOOBOO:NOT a mystery like Sherlock Holmes or "Colonel Mustard, in the drawing room, with the double-headed dildo." A mystery like how fat Americans are, or why Sting is famous. That's a fushigi.

jukugo.word: 不安 な ( ふあん な)
description: 不 (un) + 安 (cheap / safe) = 不安 (unease)

不 (un) + 倫 (principles) = 不倫 (affair)

kunyomi.meaning: 'No'. Usually used by older people. Or pretentious authors, who contradict themselves for rhetorical effect: 'She was a proper woman, No, wait, perhaps I should rather say she was the kind of woman who wanted to be seen as proper, A-ha-ha, I am so clever.'

jukugo.word: 否定形 ( ひていけい )
jukugo.meaning: a negative sentence. 'He doesn't , we don't, I can not,' are examples of English negatives. ひていけい is a good word to know if you want to ask your friends, 'How do you use this word in the negative?'

拒 (repel) + 否 (no) = 拒否 (refuse!!!!)

jukugo.meaning: the more informal, spoken word for husband (your own or other peoples') - (BOOBOO: if you're talking about someone else's man, say お旦那さん (more polite!)) (1/2 KANA)

jukugo.word: 一旦 xxxすると ( いったん xxxすると)
jukugo.meaning: once you've started to do xxx . . . (i.e. once you've gotten married, you can't get divorced! once you've promised, you can't go back on it!) (KANA)
description: 一 (one) + 旦 (danna (husband)) = 一旦 (once you've started to do xxx . . .)

mnemonic: as in,"HACK up the white people into pieces!!! Dirty swine-eating slave-drivers!"
Sun plus a dot, which we'll call, say, a blunt of marijuana, for reasons which shall become clear shortly.
RAY is a white cat, but he talks black. RAY likes to smoke a Dutch.
Picture White Ray smoking a dutch (the dot). all day .
Thus:　白

kunyomi.meaning: white

jukugo.word: 面白*い ( おもしろい )
jukugo.meaning: interesting, (in a good way) but also can mean funny (as in, laughing at you!) this deliberate ambiguity being a big thing with Japanese Sarcasm. Although in this case, fully half the time people are being serious. (SARC)
description: 面 (front surface / face) + 白 (white) = 面白*い (interesting)

jukugo.meaning: white people (do the Humpty Hump, they do the humpty hump) (NEO)
description: 白 (white) + 人 (person) = 白人 (white people)
白 (white) + 黒 (black) = 白黒 (black-and-white)

mnemonic: I compared everyone's KITES, and I think hers is the most white.

kunyomi.meaning: (sometimes also pronounced みんな）everyone.

jukugo.meaning: a more formal way to say "everyone." (F, KUNKUN)
description: 皆 (everyone) + 様 (important person) = 皆様 (everyone)

mnemonic: MUTANTS:
Water
waterleft
as in 'SEND me to the spring, I need to get my soak on!'
The pure ,white water poured out of the hot spring.

kunyomi.meaning: spring, as in water popping out of the earth

jukugo.meaning: hot spring baths (although most onsen use artificially heated water from regular wells these days)
description: 温 (hot or warm thing) + 泉 (spring) = 温泉 (hot spring bath)

mnemonic: as in, ' HE ONLY eats ice cream'

kunyomi.meaning: ice

description: 氷 (ice) + 山 (mountain) = 氷山 (iceberg)

mnemonic: "Fonzie" is the keyword for the EI onyomi, because that was his catchphrase on the show. "EYYYY!" Back in '78, that was the most coveted t-shirt: a half-sleeve jersey with The Fonz giving a thumbs-up and reciting EYYYY!! That's right, I'm old. Didn't ever get that shirt, neither!
Anyway, mnemonic-wise, we can now say that. . .. Fonzie has been icy cool since forever.

永 consists of ice (氷） plus a dot, which we will, in a blaze of inspiration, call a second snowflake. So now we can say, "It's been icy forever, so we have more than one snowflake. They're piled on top of each other! It's been snowing forever!"

jukugo.word: 永遠 に ( えいえん に)
jukugo.meaning: the poetic 'forever'： I'll hate you forever! We shall rule the world forever!
description: 永 (forever) + 遠 (far) = 永遠 (poetic forever)

jukugo.word: 永久 に ( えいきゅう に)
jukugo.meaning: forever - the science word. (BOOBOO : the poetic word is 'eien'.(永遠))
description: 永 (forever) + 久 (been a long time) = 永久 (forever )

mnemonic: Fonzie can swim in water for a long time!
description: It's easy to tell apart from 永　or 氷 - since there's 2 water radicals. Because to swim you need that much water!!!

kunyomi.meaning: swim

mnemonic: Make the white devils spend the night in a wet puddle. (This inn is Japanese only! )

kunyomi.meaning: to stay somewhere overnight
to let your friends crash at your house.

jukugo.meaning: a COUNTER for the number of nights you stay. You use this when making a reservation at a hotel. Ippaku is , of course, one night. (COUNTER)
description: 一 (one) + 泊 (stay for the night) = 一泊 (one night's stay)

jukugo.meaning: to stay somewhere for two nights.
description: 二 (two) + 泊 (stay for the night) = 二泊 (to stay somewhere for two nights.)

jukugo.word: に 宿泊 する (に しゅくはく する)
jukugo.meaning: the act of staying the night -(kind of formal; you might read it in a hotel guidebook, but you wouldn't say "Let's 宿泊 over there, guys!" (NP)
description: 宿 (lodge at) + 泊 (stay for the night) = 宿泊 (stay the night)

mnemonic: as in:JEWS are frequently down with a juice called Manichewitz!
There's like ten different liquids in this juice. -- lemon, pineapple, apple, and so on.

kunyomi.meaning: SUFFIX which means juice, or soup (as in味噌汁：みそしる； (miso soup)) , . . .also semen (ABU, SUF)

description: 果 (fruit　/ result) + 汁 (juice, soup) = 果汁 (fruit juice)

mnemonic: Mix the insects in a bowl with water and some pine CONEs, for some free and fun soup!

kunyomi.meaning: I blend the ingredients (BOOBOO: unlike the other まぜる　（交ぜる）, this word is used for technical stuff- science or cooking.
it gets mixed
to be crowded (usually in the present perfect： こんでる!)
get mixed up in a situation: wrong place, wrong time.

jukugo.word: 混乱 する ( こんらん する)
jukugo.meaning: What you are experiencing right now while studying Japanese!
description: 混 (mix) + 乱 (disorder) = 混乱 (confusion)

mnemonic: The United States had to GET TO the moon before the Russians, because whoever got freaky with Moon Bitches first would get so much rep, the other country's game would never recover.
description: JERK RADICAL ALERT: by itself, it means month or moon, but usually as a radical it has an entirely different meaning :"organ of the body." Some dudes will point out that the 月 Radical is actually a MUTANT RADICAL for 肉、but who cares? Stop being so pedantic with your pale ass.BOOBOO: when you say the actual proper names of months, you pronounce it GATsu!!!That really is hard to remember.

mnemonic: KOdomos ( 子 ) play by the lake.
The old man gets wet in the lake once a month.

kunyomi.meaning: big lake

mnemonic: When the sun or the moon is full, it MAY get bright!

kunyomi.meaning: bright , sunny weather / person with a sunny disposition.

kunyomi.word: あき＊らか ( な or に )
kunyomi.meaning: an obvious, clear difference between two things

jukugo.word: 説明 する ( せつめい する)
description: 説 (explain) + 明 (bright) = 説明 (explain)

jukugo.word: 不明 な　 or の ( ふめい な　 or の)
jukugo.meaning: unknown, unclear. (the body's identity remains unknown / an unknown tribe made these carvings of your mama's ass) (NP)
description: 不 (un) + 明 (bright) = 不明 (unknown, unclear)

jukugo.word: 明けましておめでとう ( あけまして おめでとう! )
jukugo.meaning: Happy new year! (only noobs say this before Jan 1st. In the last part of December, we say, "良いお年を!" (よいおとしを!) (BOOBOO)

mnemonic: Your Moms got so much animal fat, SHE squirts lipids out of her blow-hole!
Animal fat is not an organ, but you get the gist!!

kunyomi.meaning: animal fat

jukugo.meaning: grease or fat (refers to both the kind used in cooking, AND the kind that makes your mama's neighbors take out earthquake insurance )
description: 脂 (animal fat) + 肪 (fatty food) = 脂肪 ( grease or fat)

mnemonic: The daring husband went to the moon and came back with a good TAN.
description: No, you won't be saying 'gallbladder' very often, but you still need this kanji to describe daring daytime bank robberies or mad ninja feats: Americans say "That takes balls," but Japanese apparently say, "That takes gallbladders!"

jukugo.word: 大胆 な ( だいたん な)
jukugo.meaning: daring or bold, - not just courageous, but taking risks when you don't need to. Not just a bank-robbery, but a bank robbery at high noon, while wearing Hirohito masks!.
description: 大 (big) + 胆 (gall bladder / daring) = 大胆 (daring or bold)

mnemonic: For Margaret CHO, getting up at ten AM is very early in the morning. She swears that she can still see the moon from the night before.

kunyomi.meaning: morning

jukugo.word: 朝ごはん ( あさごはん )

jukugo.meaning: rising sun. As in, 'land of the. . .' Also as in Asahi beer. (KUNKUN)
description: 朝 (morning) + 日 (sun, day) = 朝日 (rising sun)
朝 (morning) + 刊 (edition) = 朝刊 (morning edition)

mnemonic: MUTANTS:
Fireleftside
fireleft
Firebottom
firebottom
as in, 'ENjoy this flame-broiled food!! '

kunyomi.meaning: a big fire, but not a harmful one. Like a campfire or bonfire

description: 炎 (flame) + 症 (symptom) = 炎症 (inflammation)

mnemonic: as in,"His TAN faded to pale after so many weeks indoors. "
The water pretty much doused the flame, leaving only a faint, pale flickering.

kunyomi.meaning: faint color. (薄い also means faint, but 淡い carries the connotation of, it's faint because it's weak or sickly)

mnemonic: You need to consult with Glen DANzig. Say to him, why did he start that flame? (hint: Satan)

jukugo.meaning: a joke - you'll often hear: "冗談じゃない！” ('I'm not kidding!') (1/2 KANA)
description: 冗 (joke) + 談 (consult) = 冗談 (joke)

jukugo.word: 相談 する ( そうだん する)
jukugo.meaning: a consultation - it doesn't have to be formal. If you want to see your teacher after class, that's a soudan.
description: 相 (partner) + 談 (consult) = 相談 (consult)

mnemonic: Nail radical
nailright
as in, 'The old man walked home drunk and stubbed his TOE on a streetlight. '
The streetlight stood straight like a big nail with a little electric fire on top of it.

description: 街 (shopping district) + 灯 (streetlight) = 街灯 (streetlight)

jukugo.meaning: lamp -(BOOBOO: in practice, everyone just says でんき) (NP)
description: 電 (electricity) + 灯 (streetlight) = 電灯 (lamp -(BOOBOO: in practice, everyone just says でんき) )

jukugo.word: 懐中電灯 ( かいちゅうでんとう )
description: 懐 (nostalgia) + 中 (middle) + 電灯 (lamp -(BOOBOO: in practice, everyone just says でんき) ) = 懐中電灯 (flashlight)

mnemonic: It's possible to get a CAR for cheap,if you cram a nail into the mouth of the salesman!

description: 可 (possible) + 愛 (love) = 可愛い (cute!)

jukugo.word: 可能性 の or が ( かのうせい の or が)
description: 可 (possible) + 能 (talent) + 性 (sex / essential nature) = 可能性 (possibility)
許 (allow) + 可 (possible) = 許可 (permission)

jukugo.word: 不可能 な or です。 ( ふかのう な or です。)
description: 不 (un) + 可 (possible) + 能 (talent) = 不可能 (not possible)

jukugo.word: 可燃ゴミ ( かねんごみ )
description: 可 (possible) + 燃 (burn) = 可燃ゴミ (burnable garbage)

mnemonic: It's possible to drive your car into the water of the stream. All it takes is a CAR and some booze.

kunyomi.meaning: xxx-river (proper noun!) (SUF)

jukugo.meaning: a traditional monster, one you'll still see all the time in illustrations or storefronts. They used to be crazy vicious, jumping up out of the lake and eating your intestines while you're still alive, but now they're more like cute, mischievous mascots -
description: (KANA)
河 (stream) + 童 (kid) = 河童 (the green frog-monster)

mnemonic: I'm saying to the carpenter, TAKE that nail back and revise the construction.

jukugo.meaning: to correct or revise some written thing - lyrics, a report, an article, or even (god forbid) a Kanji book.
description: 訂 (revise) + 正 (correct) = 訂正 ( correct or revise )
You'll probably see this more in people's names than you ever will see rice paddies.

kunyomi.meaning: Only used in peoples' names: 田中(たなか） is the Japanese version of Smith.

description: 田 (rice field) + 舎 (hut) = 田舎 (countryside)

mnemonic: The rice 'hood is next to the nail district.

kunyomi.meaning: a small town - but also a SUFFIX which means xxx-town. Like Levittown or Funkytown. (SUF)

mnemonic: (SIGH) ok, look: They burn the field to clear it, then they plant crops. Whatever.

kunyomi.meaning: SUFFIX meaning, "field of a particular crop". like いちご はたけ、(field of strawberries) or すいか はたけ (field of watermelons). You don't need an article like 'no' or 'na'.

mnemonic: When I eat rice from the field, I keep it in the organ called the stomach.

kunyomi.meaning: stomach

mnemonic: Unlike the lookalike 'person' kanji (人）, the top of 入　bends left, so you can say,
'I take my NEW axe and put it in your left side, you bourgeois pig!!!! '

kunyomi.meaning: I put it in (I put the dog in the doghouse)
it goes in (The dog goes in the doghouse)

description: 入 (put/go in) + 口 (mouth) = 入り口 (entrance)

jukugo.word: に 入院 する (に にゅういん する)
jukugo.meaning: check into the hospital - not for a simple exam, but like you have to stay there at least one night, you're too sick to leave.
description: 入 (put/go in) + 院 (institution) = 入院 (check in hospital)

jukugo.word: に 入学 (に にゅうがく )
jukugo.meaning: to start school at a new school
description: 入 (put/go in) + 学 (knowledge) = 入学 (to start school at a new school)

jukugo.word: 入館料 ( にゅうかんりょう )
description: 入 (put/go in) + 館 (big hall) + 料 (ingredients / fees) = 入館料 (admission fee)

mnemonic: Man
personleft

onyomi: but you don't need to learn it.
mnemonic: When you say " WHAAT????", you are asking that person if what they just said is really possible.

kunyomi.meaning: what

description: 何 (what?!?) + 時 (time) = 何時 (what time is it?)

jukugo.word: 何とか xxx ( なんとか xxx)
何だコイツ ( なんだこいつ )

jukugo.meaning: geometry (I like this because it seems that even the Chinese sages who made up this word were confused by geometry. It's like 'the science of what the fuck??') (FR, FP)
description: 幾 (how much?) + 何 (what?!?) + 学 (knowledge) = 幾何学 (geometry)

mnemonic: If they've got a SHINy halo, it's safe to believe what that person has to say .

kunyomi.meaning: believe

description: 自 (my own) + 信 (believe) = 自信 (self-confidence)
信 (believe) + 号 (number) = 信号 (signal)
迷 (perplexed) + 信 (believe) = 迷信 (superstition)

mnemonic: The CAR transforms into Optimus Prime.
OK, I know he's supposed to be a truck or whatever, but I never liked that show anyway. I was fucking with Papa Smurf and Raydeen and shit.
The witch transformed that person into a giant heel.
description: You'll often see 化 as a suffix, meaning "xxx - ization." For instance, 機械化(きかいか）means "the mechanization of society. The industrial revolution." Most of these words are not worth learning, but there's a LOT of them, so at least learn the suffix meaning.

kunyomi.meaning: transform - this is ONLY used in the context of a person changing to a ghost, or a curse transforming a person into a werewolf. In other words, it is not used that often.

jukugo.word: 変化 する ( へんか する)
description: 変 (change) + 化 (transform) = 変化 (transformation, change)
文 (culture/ sentence) + 化 (transform) = 文化 (culture)
進 (progress) + 化 (transform) = 進化 (evolution)

jukugo.meaning: the mechanization of a society or of an industry.
description: 機械 (A machine, particularly something with a motor in it which moves when activated. A computer is not a 機会, but a robot arm is. ) + 化 (transform) = 機械化 (mechanization )

mnemonic: MUTANTS:
Flower
flowertop
as in, 'My KUCHI ( 口 ) was suffering from too much candy. '
The old flower was suffering : wilting, turning brown, being eaten by aphids.

kunyomi.meaning: bitter taste ー medicine, okra. Can also be used figuratively - the bitter taste of defeat.
adjective describing mental suffering - which is caused BY 痛み　(physical pain). i.e. 'My throat is 痛い、 so talking or swallowing is 苦しい’
to hurt or suffer　from XXX

description: 苦 (suffer) + 労 (labor) = 苦労 (hardships)

jukugo.word: xxxは 苦手 (xxxは にがて )
jukugo.meaning: this has 2 meanings. One is "I'm not good at this" and the second is "I don't like this" Clever Japanese! (KUNKUN)
description: 苦 (suffer) + 手 (hand) = 苦手 (this is not my thing!)
苦 (suffer) + 情 (emotion) = 苦情 (a grievance or complaint )

mnemonic: The flowers of the grass bloom SO early in the sun.

kunyomi.meaning: grass - tall, uncut grass.(BOOBOO: In practice, though, most people use　芝生 (しばふ）)

mnemonic: What kind of idiot puts a flower in the luggage in their CAR??? It'll get crushed for sure!
description: COCK: 99% of the time the onyomi is KA- but the one jukugo that anyone ever fuckin' actually USES, the onyomi is NI.

jukugo.meaning: luggage or belongings. Also, cargo (if you're a ship's captain). Also, emotional baggage, or a metaphorical burden (FP)
description: 荷 (luggage) + 物 (animal / thing) = 荷物 (luggage)

mnemonic: It's NICE to be a person trapped inside George Michael's stache?

kunyomi.meaning: inside a thing, OR inside of a certain time frame(eat it while it's hot! 温かい内に食べて!) Also, it's a slang term for 'us.'

jukugo.meaning: the contents (of a box or a book or whatever)
description: 内 (the inside) + 容 (appearance) = 内容 (contents)

jukugo.word: 案内 する ( あんない する)
jukugo.meaning: a guide - usually in the form of a map, or an information kiosk. Also if a clerk shows you around a store pointing out things you might want to buy, that 's annai.
description: 案 (guide/proposal) + 内 (the inside) = 案内 (guide)

jukugo.meaning: within xxx (as in, "I'll be there within 10 minutes!")
description: 以 (compared to) + 内 (the inside) = 以内 (within)

jukugo.meaning: usually defined as 'confidential,' but that makes it sound more serious than it is - like a spy document or something. Actually, 内緒 is kind of a kids' word. "Keep this information between us two." (KIDS)
description: 内 (the inside) + 緒 (together) = 内緒 (confidential)

mnemonic: George has got two men's meat trapped in his 'stache. He particularly NEEds COOlio's meat. Of course it might just be easier to think of it as 2 pork chops, but I prefer the more lurid imagery.

kunyomi.meaning: meat, muscle (LAZY)

description: 筋 (muscle) + 肉 (meat) = 筋肉 (muscle)

jukugo.meaning: sarcasm OR irony. Japanese DO have a sense of sarcasm,(for example, calling the traditional chicken-and-scrambled-eggs dish "parents and child") but it is so different than the Western say-the-opposite-of-what-you-mean style that Japanese don't have a word for western sarc. So they seem to have taken their word for Irony and pressed it into service for sarcasm as well. (SARC)
description: 皮 (skin) + 肉 (meat) = 皮肉 (sarcasm/irony)
豚 (pig) + 肉 (meat) = 豚肉 (pork )
焼 (roast / grill) + 肉 (meat) = 焼肉 (roast meat, usually beef.)
牛 (cow) + 肉 (meat) = 牛肉 (beef)

mnemonic: This one consists of George Michael's Moustache, plus 2 boxes, which we'll call his gleaming front teeth.
If you ENjoyed George Michael's Moustache, please tip him one yen.
In response, he smiles, you can see his two front teeth peeking at you from under the 'stache.

kunyomi.meaning: circircular　(not used! People use the OTHER まるい　（丸い） instead)
yen!

description: 十 (ten) + 円 (yen/circle) = 十円 (ten yen.)

jukugo.word: 七千円 ( ななせんえん )
description: 七 (seven) + 千 (thousand) + 円 (yen/circle) = 七千円 (７，０００ yen.)
百 (hundred) + 円 (yen/circle) = 百円 (１００ yen)

jukugo.word: 一億円 ( いちおくえん )
description: 一 (one) + 億 (a hundred million) + 円 (yen/circle) = 一億円 (100,000,000 YEN)

kunyomi.meaning: my older sister
someone else's older sister.

kunyomi.meaning: 姉 (older sister) + 妹 (little sister) = 姉妹 (sisters)

kunyomi.meaning: to risk xxx (grave danger/ your life/ your anal virginity) doing crazy shit

description: 冒 (risk) + 険 (steep) = 冒険 (adventure)

Wear a hat to protect yourself from danger such as daggers.

description: 帽 (hat) + 子 (child) = 帽子 (hat)

mnemonic: 自 is "eye" plus a dot, which we'll call a splinter.
JESUS said, before you make fun of the splinter in my eye, take check out the huge-ass log in YOUR OWN eye. Then he sort of muttered, "Ass!"

kunyomi.meaning: to do something one's own self, in person

jukugo.word: 自由 な ( じゆう な)
description: 自 (my own) + 由 (freedom / reason) = 自由 (freedom)

jukugo.word: 自分 の ( じぶん の)
jukugo.meaning: one's own (dog, blunt, fungus, etc.) - BOOBOO: sometimes it also is used to mean "you" or "she", as in "She did it herself, as opposed to having others do it for her."
description: 自 (my own) + 分 (understand / divide / minute) = 自分 (one's own)
自 (my own) + 信 (believe) = 自信 (self-confidence)

jukugo.word: 自業自得 ( じごうじとく )
description: 自 (my own) + 業 (business) + 得 (bargain　/ obtain) = 自業自得 ("I brought this on myself!")

jukugo.meaning: SUFFIX, meaning 'name of restaurant' . So you can tell "Joe's亭" (Joe's diner)　apart from "Joe's本屋"　（Joe's bookstore) (SUF)

mnemonic: The police person brings a halt to the restaurant because too many people got a damn nail in their sandwitch and what the hell kind of deal is that, anyway? Imagine the pain!!

jukugo.word: 停止 する ( ていし する)
jukugo.meaning: suspension or stoppage (i.e. they cut my electricity because I didn't pay the bill). This is usually used in official announcements or bills. You wouldn't say to your friend, "I 停止-ed watching TV." (NP)

jukugo.word: 各駅停車 ( かくえきていしゃ )
jukugo.meaning: sure this is a scary and long word, but if you live here, you'll use it everyday： It means "local train" (literally, "stopping at each station train")

jukugo.word: 卒業 する ( そつぎょう する)
description: 卒 (graduate) + 業 (business) = 卒業 (to graduate)

mnemonic: You go in that direction of a a fine-looking HOE who is wearin' a beret!

description: Japanese count big money in units of 10,000. They don't for instance, have a word for 'million.' -- a million is actually called 100万. Which would be logical if it were written with 万-sized commas： 100,0000 . . . but it's written with rest-of-the-planet commas, like this: 1,000,000. I'm sure some asshole thought he was doing the rest of the world a favor with this compromise, but actually that just makes it more confusing for everyone. Probably it was the same motherless douche who decided to import all the on-yomi from China and get them all wrong.Anyway.

jukugo.word: 我慢 する ( がまん する)
jukugo.meaning: to endure, to bear something. Often translated as 'patience,' but that is not quite right. You have patience if you can do data entry on a fucking kanji dictionary for 5 hours straight, but you gaman with your overtime or while taking final exams with a burst appendix.
description: Masochists tend to gaman when they're fed worms while tied up.
Sometimes the concept of gaman DOES overlap with the English idea of patience, though: Little kids have to gaman if they find out that Disneyland is still 4 hours away.

One possible way to make GAMAN fit with the theme of 'neglect' is to remember that the 'ga' part means 'self.' So GAMAN means 'neglect yourself,' or, more poetically, 'Stop feeling the pain of your body and mind, and concentrate on the task at hand.' (CCW, 1/2 KANA)
我 (we) + 慢 (neglect/ egotistic) = 我慢 (persevere)

description: BOOBOO: people think this means "ASIA," but it doesn't. A while ago, just as a pun, some Japanese decided to spell the word "ASIA" phonetically, using kanji, like so: 亜細亜：あじあ: but this custom never caught on. And besides, the 亜 kanji was only chosen for its sound, not for its meaning.亜 is used in a lot of names of elements, like chalk or zinc, but unless you're a research chemist or terrorist, this doesn't concern you.

kunyomi.meaning: absolute darkness

mnemonic: It CAN take a period of time of up to a day to go from one gate (門) to the other.

kunyomi.meaning: an interval of time - the time between event A and event B.
gate - never used by itself, though. Only in jukugo - sort of like a second ONyomi. (see below!) (NUBI)

description: 時 (time) + 間 (a period of time) = 時間 (time)
間 (a period of time) + 違 (different and therefore wrong) = 間違い (a mistake)
You can't just say "one year" like in English. You have to add 'kan', the equivalent of saying, in English, 'one year's time.'
for instance:
一年間 (いちねんかん）:one year's time
三週間 (さんしゅうかん）: three weeks' time
With months, it gets even more complex: you have to add 間 at the end AND ヶ (pronounced 'ka') in the middle, like this:
三ヶ月間 (さんかげつかん）: three months' time (SUF)
人 (person) + 間 (a period of time) = 人間 (human)

jukugo.word: に 間に合う (に まにあう )
jukugo.meaning: to make it in time - catching your train or not being late for class (this is the main time you use the "MA" pronunciation)

description: The era doesn't use the Emperor's real name, but his official nickname, which seems a bit informal, but try being logical with an emperor-lover and see where it gets you.
Anyway, the Showa era, according to wikipedia, was from 1926-1989. (CCW)
昭 (shining / Showa era) + 和 (peace/ Japan) = 昭和 (Showa Era)

jukugo.meaning: nickname of Emperor Hirohito - from which the Era got its name. (CCW)
description: 昭 (shining / Showa era) + 和 (peace/ Japan) = 昭和 (Hirohito's nickname)

jukugo.word: 一緒 に ( いっしょ に)
description: 一 (one) + 緒 (together) = 一緒 (together)

jukugo.meaning: usually defined as 'confidential,' but that makes it sound more serious than it is - like a spy document or something. Actually, 内緒 is kind of a kids' word. "Keep this information between us two." (KIDS)
description: 内 (the inside) + 緒 (together) = 内緒 (confidential)

mnemonic: s.h.o. stands for :SEE HER various OCELOTS.
Go talk to various professionals about doing the job.

kunyomi.meaning: JUKUGO:

kunyomi.word: Gentlemen! My friends! (Usually used by an upper person addressing a crowd of lower people, like a speech situation) (F)
kunyomi.meaning: 諸 (various) + 君 (buddy) = 諸君 (Gentlemen!)
PREFIX meaning 'various XXX' (usually used with countries, opinions, factions, problems ,etc.) (pretty much the same as the '々' kanji) (PRE)

mnemonic: I SAW HER OCELOTS at the government office.
The government office is a net where professional bureaucrats are caught for the day.

jukugo.word: 警察署 ( けいさつしょ )
description: 警察 (police) + 署 (government office) = 警察署 (police station)

jukugo.word: 消防署 ( しょうぼうしょ )
description: 消 (erase) + 防 (ward off) + 署 (government office) = 消防署 (fire station)

jukugo.word: 署名 する ( しょめい する)
jukugo.meaning: to sign an official document.(this sounds useless, but if you go to do any paperwork with the immigration people, they'll give you a form with this word on it) (NP)
description: 署 (government office) + 名 (name, famous) = 署名 (sign an official document)

mnemonic: Hot sunshine roasts the professional.

kunyomi.meaning: hot weather, a place with a hot climate

jukugo.word: 蒸し暑い ( むしあつい )
description: 蒸 (humid) + 暑 (hot place) = 蒸し暑い (humid)

mnemonic: The professional cook SHALL always stew food using fire, not a damn microwave.

kunyomi.meaning: boil (potato) or simmer (a sauce or stew or onabe)
it gets boiled or cooked

description: 煮 (simmer/stew) + 物 (animal / thing) = 煮物 (boiled food)
I swear, that is what all the books say! This is much more complex than most radicals. On the good side, though, it is so common that you can't NOT learn it.

mnemonic: Don't SHOW off your cooking, that roast turkey is pretty clearly scorched in the fire.

kunyomi.meaning: to char or scortch. Like char-broiled beef. Also, often used with hot, passionate emotions: burning with the fiiiire of looooooveeeee!!!!!!!!!!!!
it gets scorched
to be in a hurry, impatient (KANA)

mnemonic: you can't say MOO without a cow!
OK, this is basically like "scorch" kanji ( 焦）　but WITHOUT the little 'head' in the center: The top of 無 is flat, WITHOUT a 'head'.
description: This is the kanji for ない, although it is seldom used anymore.

kunyomi.meaning: SUFFIX which turns the previous word into a negative. 金＝money。 金無い＝ no money. (KANA)

jukugo.meaning: free (not like Martin Luther King, I mean free like a free magazine full of articles on how to become a stripper)
description: 無 (without) + 料 (ingredients / fees) = 無料 (free)
無 (without) + 理 (reason) = 無理 (impossible)

jukugo.word: 無視 する ( むし する)
jukugo.meaning: to ignore or snub someone or something.
description: 無 (without) + 視 (peer at) = 無視 (to ignore or snub someone or something.)

jukugo.word: xxx　の 無駄 (xxx　の むだ )
jukugo.meaning: a waste of something (time, money) (1/2 KANA)
description: 無 (without) + 駄 (bad quality) = 無駄 (waste )

mnemonic: I am responsible for the upkeep of this turkey, so I always keep a string tied around his neck so he can't run away.

jukugo.word: 維持 する ( いじ する)
jukugo.meaning: to maintain or sustain something (the quality of our products, our 10% lead in the polls, maintaining the giant robot takes 3 hours a day)
description: 維 (upkeep) + 持 (hold) = 維持 (ｍａｉｎｔａｉｎ　ｏｒ　ｓｕｓｔａｉｎ)
維持 (to maintain or sustain something (the quality of our products, our 10% lead in the polls, maintaining the giant robot takes 3 hours a day) ) + 費 (expenses) = 維持費 (maintenance costs.)

mnemonic: HUEY Newton is the sole Black Panther to french-kiss a turkey with his mouth.

jukugo.word: 唯一 のXXX ( ゆいいつ のXXX)
description: 唯 (sole or only) + 一 (one) = 唯一 (the only, the sole XXX)

mnemonic: Who said that was my turkey?

kunyomi.meaning: who???

jukugo.meaning: someone (related word: 誰かさん＝ Old What's-His-Face)

mnemonic: In JUNE, I prepare ten turkeys by washing them with water

jukugo.word: 準備 する ( じゅんび する)
jukugo.meaning: this is the main word you'll use with this kanji: prepare (packing for a vacation, getting the restaurant ready to open for the day, and putting on makeup are all junbi).
description: 準 (prepare / criteria) + 備 (furnish) = 準備 (get ready)

jukugo.meaning: criterion - the basis for judging a sex partner, potential job applicant, which songs to buy, etc. Also - unlike the OTHER きじゅん （規準）、THIS きじゅん ALSO has a second meaning: 'standard', as in, standard wages, standard price, the gold standard, standard medical ethics. Metric is our standard of measurement in Japan, whereas in USA they use their own standard.
description: 基 (basis) + 準 (prepare / criteria) = 基準 (a standard )
規 (criteria) + 準 (prepare / criteria) = 規準 (a criterion)

mnemonic: He's so crooked he needed FIVE (=五, pronounced GO) lawyers to defend him!
Defend the flower from the turkey's crotch by talking to it (the pervert turkey) politely but firmly.

description: 看 (observe/guard) + 護 (defend) + 師 (master, teacher) = 看護師 (nurse)

jukugo.meaning: Defense attorney (BOOBOO: it's often translated as 'lawyer,' but べんごし usually handle criminal cases - murder, arson, etc. Lawsuits or legal procedures related to your visa are either handled by a sort of freelance bureaucrat/notary or by the mob. )
description: 弁 (dialect) + 護 (defend) + 士 (samurai radical) = 弁護士 (Defense attorney)

jukugo.word: 保護 する ( ほご する)
jukugo.meaning: conserve, protect : used about protecting nature and the environment. But usually used with police protection (for snitches) or if you're escorting a lost child or drunk to the police box. (BOOBOO: conservative person is　保守的な　（ほしゅてきな）　人)
description: 保 (guarantee/maintain ) + 護 (defend) = 保護 (conserve, protect)
護 (defend) + 衛 (defense) = 護衛 (a bodyguard, an escort)

mnemonic: Get a BARBER to shave your horse. One thing I can't effing stand, it's a hairy horse.
This is turkey + 4 dots (usually this is the 'flame' radical, but in this case, let's make an exception and call them 'hooves.')
So, you can say . . .
A horse is basically a giant turkey with 4 hooves .

kunyomi.meaning: HORSE

description: 競 (contest) + 馬 (horse) = 競馬 (horse racing)

mnemonic: SHE stopped you from having a good time.
Picture your foot, with her spiked heel stomping on your instep - you can't walk. You been STOPPED.

kunyomi.meaning: I stop it
it gets stopped

jukugo.word: 中止 された ( ちゅうし された)
jukugo.meaning: (temporarily) stopped or (permanently) canceled. This is a word you'd hear in an announcement. You wouldn't say to your friend, "I'm going to 中止 watching TV for a week." (NP)
description: 中 (middle) + 止 (stop) = 中止 (stop/cancel)

jukugo.word: 痛み止め ( いたみどめ )
jukugo.meaning: pain-killer, like aspirin. (BOOBOO: not anaesthetic, which is 麻酔（ますい） )
description: 痛 (hurts!!!) + 止 (stop) = 痛み止め (pain-killer,)

mnemonic: SHE stopped a female turkey by kicking it with her heel.

jukugo.meaning: PREFIX meaning 'female animal.' For example, 雌犬(めすいぬ) female dog - which does NOT mean 'beyatch' in the English sexist sense. (PRE)
female pig - oddly, THIS is the one that means "Biiiitch!" (KUN ON)
description: 雌 (your Moms) + 豚 (pig) = 雌豚 (female pig)

mnemonic: Once a month I consent to stop doing COCAINE and rest.

jukugo.word: 肯定 する ( こうてい する)
jukugo.meaning: to admit to, or affirm something. (opp: 否定　（ひてい）meaning, to deny) (NP)
description: 肯 (consent) + 定 (plan) = 肯定 (affirm)

mnemonic: I walked across the street to avoid the Hairy Obese.
When you go for a walk, stop a little to enjoy the view.

kunyomi.meaning: to walk

description: 歩 (walk) + 道 (street) = 歩道 (sidewalk)

jukugo.word: 散歩 する ( さんぽ する)
jukugo.meaning: a stroll, to walk with no particular destination
description: 散 (scatter) + 歩 (walk) = 散歩 (a stroll)

jukugo.word: 歩行者 ( ほこうしゃ )
description: 歩 (walk) + 行 (go) + 者 (professional) = 歩行者 (pedestrian)

mnemonic: if you interfere with my business, I'll SHOW you the door.
All this water interferes with my walking across the ocean.

jukugo.word: 干渉 する ( かんしょう する)
description: 干 (dry out) + 渉 (interfere) = 干渉 (interfere or meddle.)

jukugo.word: 交渉 する ( こうしょう する)
description: 交 (combine) + 渉 (interfere) = 交渉 (negotiate )

mnemonic: SHE won't stop wearing a purple string on her heel! (I have asked)

kunyomi.meaning: purple

mnemonic: A mouth yelling "Stop right now and put a damn SOCK on your foot!!! You'll catch cold running around like that!! Do you know what kind of germs are on the ground?? do you know what kind of people have been here????!"
description: JERK - It means both foot and "to be enough". . . maybe a foot-fetishist made this one up??Also, jukugo of 足 tend to be KUNKUN, rather than ON-ON.

kunyomi.meaning: to be enough. Often used in the negative. XXXが足りない!
means foot AND leg. Oops. They don't have a separate word.

jukugo.meaning: To not have enough of a physical thing (money, time, nurses, teachers.) Also implies that there is a specific amount that is required, For example -犬不足 (a dog shortage). There's no particle or verb needed. (NP)
description: 不 (un) + 足 (foot/ be enough) = 不足 (shortage of)

jukugo.word: 満足 する ( まんぞく する)
description: 満 (full) + 足 (foot/ be enough) = 満足 (to be totally satisfied.)
足 (foot/ be enough) + 首 (neck) = 足首 (ankle)

mnemonic: Peer pressure is when you make a person wear the same SOCKS on their feet that you do.

kunyomi.meaning: to press or encouarge someone to do something. Could be good, as in "Get up and dance! It's a party! Have some fun!" or bad, as in, "Work faster! If there's time to lean, there's time to clean!"

jukugo.word: 催促 する ( さいそく する)
jukugo.meaning: to repeat and repeat a demand. Can be used about corporations (This is your 3d notice of overdue library book) or between frends, ('I keep asking you to repay that $5 I lent you')
description: 催 (sponsor) + 促 (peer pressure) = 催促 (repeatedly request)

mnemonic: Don't tread on my TOEs!
A foot treads on a water puddle, shattering its reflection of the sun.
description: There's a bunch of jukugo, but I can't find any that are useful.

kunyomi.meaning: tread on

mnemonic: Don't just SAY that you'll act correct, you gotta SHOW me.
Stop using ONE pair of underpants all week. Act correct with your hygiene!

kunyomi.meaning: correct, in BOTH senses : literally , as in a correct answer. (Implies that there is ONLY ONE correct one). And figuratively: something that is morally correct or just.

jukugo.word: 正直 な ( しょうじき な)
jukugo.meaning: very honest person, very loyal. Person with integrity. Also means, "To tell you the truth. . . xxxx"
description: 正 (correct) + 直 (correct a probem / direct contact) = 正直 (honest / loyal)
正 (correct) + 解 (solve / untie) = 正解 (correct answer)

jukugo.word: 正確 な ( せいかく な)
jukugo.meaning: accurate, precise (used about machines, not people)
description: 正 (correct) + 確 (make certain) = 正確 (precise)

mnemonic: Fer shure, THEY will do it correctly every day! (they are down like that)

description: 1) in casual conversation, starting a sentence with 'zehi' means, 'Absolutely!' 'I'll get it done by hook or by crook!' - also, you'll hear 'ぜひおねがいします！' a lot, which means 'Thanks in advance for this favor.' . . . .
2) the propriety or morality of a certain course of action ( the kanji themselves translate to 'right + injustice'). (1/2 KANA)
是 (fer shure) + 非 (injustice / mistake) = 是非 (absolutely!)

mnemonic: If you are going to be a king, you have to plan to TAKE the correct crown.

kunyomi.meaning: to ordain or determine (either a rule, a plan, or a time and place for something).

jukugo.meaning: an informal plan (like to meet your friends for a movie)
description: 予 (beforehand) + 定 (plan) = 予定 (an informal plan)

jukugo.word: 設定 する ( せってい する)
jukugo.meaning: to establish a regulation or rule - also it is often seen on the 'setup' or 'preferences' menus of software when you install it.
description: 設 (establish) + 定 (plan) = 設定 (establish)

jukugo.word: 決定 する ( けってい する)
jukugo.meaning: to make a real serious decision； like, "I know I'm always saying I'm going to lose 1２ pounds but this time I really mean it."
description: 決 (decide) + 定 (plan) = 決定 (make a serious decision)
定 (plan) + 義 (righteousness) = 定義 (definition)

mnemonic: SHOW me proof that your boobs are real and not cheap counterfeits.
The cop said, "If you can talk to me and show me correct proof , you're good to go. "

kunyomi.meaning: evidence, testimony . . .: somewhere in between 証明（しょうめい: proof）　and 証拠　（しょうこ: phsyical evidence）. You'd typically use 証 when you're talking about evidence of god such as miracles. Or you'd challenge someone "You say you're honest and give to charity, but do you have any evidence of this?" Unlike 証拠、　証　does not have to be physical, it can be verbal.

jukugo.word: 運転免許証 ( うんてん めんきょしょ )
description: 運転 (drive a vehicle) + 免許 (an exemption from something, or a license to do something. (i.e. drivers' license: 運転免許証 (うんてん　めんきょ　しょう）) + 証 (proof) = 運転免許証 (drivers' license)

jukugo.meaning: physical evidence, such as a footprint, or "This green tap-water is evidence of pollution." Also this is the word one uses about evidence at trials, not 証. (FP, NP)
description: 証 (proof) + 拠 (evidence which is the basis for a judgment) = 証拠 (physical evidence)

jukugo.word: 証明書 ( しょうめいしょ )
jukugo.meaning: a legal document certifying something: that you're married, that you have a job, that you paid tax, that you ...
description: 証 (proof) + 明 (bright) + 書 (write) = 証明書 (legal certification)

mnemonic: When something is distorted, it turns into an un-correct shape.

kunyomi.meaning: distort or deform.

mnemonic: He runs SO much because it's more correct for the earth than driving. Which is cool and all, but Some One doesn't have to be all preachy about it.

kunyomi.meaning: run

jukugo.word: 暴走族 ( ぼうそうぞく )
description: 暴 (rampage) + 走 (run) + 族 (family) = 暴走族 (Japanese bikers. )

jukugo.meaning: the more literal word for race: racing cars, sprinting, marathons, etc.
description: 競 (contest) + 走 (run) = 競走 (race)

mnemonic: Margaret CHOU goes over a tall wall in search of a Snickers.
Summon the courage to run farther than you have ever run before, go over the hills and mountains!
description: This means 'exceed a numerical value'. Not like exceed one's patience or my band exceeds your band.

kunyomi.meaning: to exceed or go over a certain limit (the cook heated the oven to over 100 degrees, the dude passed 100 years old, the man bet over 40,000 dollars, etc.)
exceed, to go past　（ａ　ｃｉｔｙ，　ａ　ｒｉｖｅｒ　，　ｅｔｃ） also go past in time (survive the winter) or surpass something (wins surpass losses, profits surpass debts).

jukugo.word: 超 ｘｘｘ ( ちょう ｘｘｘ)
超自然的 な ( ちょうしぜんてき な)
description: 超 (exceed/ go over) + 自 (my own) + 然 (nature) + 的 (motivation / '-al') = 超自然的 (supernatural)
This OBSOLETE kanji is almost never used as a word anymore, but as a radical you will see it often.That's why I gave it a new meaning. ROCK. because it looks like an "R"

mnemonic: Ride your horse to the train station to hear some rock music played by buskers outside.

kunyomi.meaning: station (LAZY)

description: 駅 (train station) + 員 (clerk) = 駅員 (train station staff. )

jukugo.word: 各駅停車 ( かくえきていしゃ )
jukugo.meaning: sure this is a scary and long word, but if you live here, you'll use it everyday： It means "local train" (literally, "stopping at each station train")
description: 各 (each) + 駅 (train station) + 停 (bring to a halt) + 車 (car) = 各駅停車 (local train)

mnemonic: My husband eats rocks for lunch at noon.

kunyomi.meaning: noon

jukugo.word: 昼ごはん ( ひるごはん )
昼寝 する ( ひるね する)
description: 昼 (noon) + 寝 (go to bed) = 昼寝 (a nap)

jukugo.word: 昼休み ( ひるやすみ )
description: 昼 (noon) + 休 (rest) = 昼休み (lunch-break )

mnemonic: Please give me a reason to translate what the YAK is saying into a rock song.

kunyomi.meaning: the reason for something
JUKUGO:

kunyomi.word: excuse, as in, 'But my mom's not fat, she's just big-boned.' (actually, she IS, often, but not in the way you meant it)
kunyomi.meaning: 言 (say) + 訳 (reason / translation) = 言い訳 (excuse)

kunyomi.word: 翻訳 する ( ほんやく する)
kunyomi.meaning: translate. sometimes shortened to 訳す (yakusu)

kunyomi.word: 申し訳ない ( もうしわけない )
kunyomi.meaning: really really really sorry. That your mom got big-boned. (F)
通訳 ( つうやく )

kunyomi.word: 通 (pass) + 訳 (reason / translation) = 通訳 (simultaneous translation)

mnemonic: TALK TO Ozzy about performing at the swamp!
We are gonna have a wet rock show in the swamp.
description: Probably the most ridiculous jerk kanji after 討、which means 'strike down / discuss.'

kunyomi.meaning: swamp

description: 沢 (swamp / bling) + 山 (mountain) = 沢山 (hell of many. )

jukugo.word: 贅沢 な ( ぜいたく な)
jukugo.meaning: extravagant (luxurious in a bad way) (1/2 KANA)

mnemonic: Hand
handleft
I only TALK to selected people.
Vanna white on Wheel of Fortune reaches out her hand and selects the glowing “R".

jukugo.word: 選択 する ( せんたく する)
jukugo.meaning: choice- somewhat more formal than 選ぶ - you'd 選ぶ a bagel but 選択 a President. (F)
description: 選 (choose) + 択 (select) = 選択 (to choose)

mnemonic: Judging from how much sugar the recipe calls for, I can infer that it will be SWEET.
Even blindfolded, I can use my hands to infer that you are a turkey -- feeling your wattle especially gives me a weird thrill.

jukugo.word: 推測 する ( すいそく する)
jukugo.meaning: speculate. Kind of formal: "It's too early to speculate about the economy." "Scientists speculate that..." (NP)
description: 推 (infer) + 測 (scientific measurment) = 推測 (speculate.)

jukugo.meaning: a guess, an estimate (i.e. estimate the price of a repair) (NP)
description: 推 (infer) + 定 (plan) = 推定 (estimate)
推 (infer) + 理 (reason) = 推理 (deductive reasoning, inference.)

mnemonic: Sketch sort of wavy lines coming off of the bum, to depict his B.O. Flies also help.
Use your hand to depict a flower growing in the middle of the rice field .

kunyomi.meaning: to sketch - a picture, as opposed to the other かく　(書く） which means to write words

jukugo.word: 描写 する ( びょうしゃ する)
jukugo.meaning: a depiction or representation of something (literally, as in 'this film contains graphic depictions of violence' or figuratively, as in 'Describe his personality to me.') (NP)
description: 描 (depict) + 写 (copy) = 描写 (depiction )

mnemonic: Fer shure I will TAKE your proposal in my hand all the way to the president!
description: 。。。also means "make an offering"

jukugo.word: 提案 する ( ていあんする する)
jukugo.meaning: a proposal - not just in business but also in everyday life : "Let's go to this movie!"
description: 提 (submit a proposal) + 案 (guide/proposal) = 提案 (proposal)

jukugo.word: 提出 する ( ていしゅつ する)
jukugo.meaning: to physically present or submit (a report, a document)
description: 提 (submit a proposal) + 出 (pull out / hand over) = 提出 (hand over / present)

mnemonic: I use my hand to pay for the moocow.

kunyomi.meaning: pay

jukugo.word: 酔っ払い ( よっぱらい )
description: 酔 (drunk) + 払 (pay) = 酔っ払い (drunk)

jukugo.word: 払い戻す ( はらいもどす )
jukugo.meaning: give me my money back, you shystey douchetool.
description: 払 (pay) + 戻 (return) = 払い戻す (refund)

mnemonic: HE called bullshit on me.
I compared my kanji dictionary to yours, and then said bullshit and flipped you the finger!

jukugo.word: 批判 する ( ひはん する)
jukugo.meaning: criticism, like "I call bullshit on the government!" or "I call bullshit on your opinion of an athlete!"
description: 批 (call bullshit on) + 判 (seal / stamp) = 批判 (criticism)

jukugo.word: 批評 する ( ひひょう する)
jukugo.meaning: review of one specific performance (showbiz event, exhibition, play, etc.) More commonly used as a verb. (NP)
description: 批 (call bullshit on) + 評 (art or literary criticism) = 批評 (review )

mnemonic: SHE points with her hand to emphasize the gist of her argument.

kunyomi.meaning: finger
literally point at. Figuratively, point to (i.e. these economic indicators point to a recession) Also means aim for. (the title belt).

jukugo.word: 指摘 する ( してき する)
jukugo.meaning: To point out a shortcoming - You can use it about your friends. Or "The critic pointed out the shortcomings of the play."
description: 指 (finger / point at) + 摘 (pluck) = 指摘 (To point out a shortcoming)

jukugo.word: 人差し指 ( ひとさしゆび )
description: 人 (person) + 差 (discriminate) + 指 (finger / point at) = 人差し指 (index finger)

jukugo.meaning: instructions　ー not like instructions from your boss, but like the instruction manual you get with your new vacuum cleaner.
description: 指 (finger / point at) + 示 (show) = 指示 (instructions　)

mnemonic: I pound a nail with my hand.
description: most of the jukugo using this have to do with baseball, which is so stupid I won't even list them.

kunyomi.meaning: to pound or strike with a tool (not your hands).

mnemonic: SHOW me how to summon a demon by beckoning with my bare hands

kunyomi.meaning: invite, summon (a person, or, more frequently, luck - usually bad, like the English prhase 'tempting fate'))

jukugo.word: 招き猫 ( まねきねこ )
jukugo.meaning: the little cat in all the shop windows. It's kind of a weird phenomenon if you think about it: One paw is up, beckoning customers to come in, like "Come on in, guy! I like your style!" But the other paw clutches a gold coin, usually marked 10,000,000 yen. Like "OK, J/K about valuing you. I just want your money." (CCW)
description: 招 (beckon) + 猫 (cat) = 招き猫 (shop-window cat)

jukugo.word: 招待 する ( しょうたい する)
description: 招 (beckon) + 待 (wait) = 招待 (invite)

mnemonic: The kidnapper stole the child and flew away on a KITE.
The kidnapper's hand held a sword, up to the mouth of the victim.

jukugo.word: 誘拐 する ( ゆうかい する)

You get a bad TAN from using your hands to carry the sun on your back.

description: 挿 (insert) + 入 (put/go in) = 挿入 (to insert)

jukugo.word: 悪趣味 ( あくしゅみ )
description: 悪 (bad) + 趣味 (hobby) = 悪趣味 (bad habit)

a disgrace! (usually used like 恥をかける） (NUBI)

description: 盗 (steal by stealth) + 聞 (listen) = 盗み聞き (to eavesdrop)

BE is a SUFFIX, which can be put after any noun, meaning 'in the vicinity of': the ocean, the university, the table, etc. You can tell 'be' and 'hen' (above) apart because 'be' always comes after a proper noun- it's a SUFFIX. (SUF)

迫害 ( はくがい )

While moving towards the hoe, he made a statement about the dot on her lip.

It's a sort of share-cropper system!

mnemonic: I'm not yet the perfect ME.
未 is basically 末, but with a SHORTER upper stroke. . HOW TO TELL THEM APART;
未-tip - SHORT UPPER BRANCH on the tree
末 - not yet - LONG UPPER BRANCH on the tree
The MADA tree, the extra branch has not yet fully grown, that's why it is shorter than the middle one.
The SUE tree, however, the extra branch has grown ALL THE WAY TO THE TIP, which is why it's LONGER than the middle one.

kunyomi.meaning: to inherit. Or to get a job because the last person quit. Or to become king, because the old king got mysteriously sick and died.

description: 跡 (vestiges) + 継 (succeed / inherit) = 跡継ぎ (heir/heiress)

jukugo.word: 継続 する ( けいぞく する)
jukugo.meaning: to carry on (the family business / a tradition)
description: 継 (succeed / inherit) + 続 (continue) = 継続 (to carry on)

mnemonic: The fortuneteller predicts raiNEN (= next year = 来年) by throwing rice and seeing what the rice sticks to.

kunyomi.meaning: to be sticky - usually shortened to the onomopoetic word ネバネバ! (1/2 KANA)
no matter how many times I try xxx, I can't do it.

jukugo.meaning: clay. (BOOBOO : but not the finished pottery, which is '陶器', or 'とうき')
description: 粘 (be sticky) + 土 (earth) = 粘土 (clay)

jukugo.meaning: adhesive- like tape, glue, or maybe even velcro?
description: 粘 (be sticky) + 着 (wear / arrive) = 粘着 (adhesive)

mnemonic: SIGH as you are forced by your stupid jerkface parents to eat cauliflower BUT IT LOOKS LIKE A BRAIN AND YOU KNOW THIS, WHY ARE YOU DOING THIS TO MEEEEE?!?!??
I eat flowers and rice with my vegetables.

description: 野 (field) + 菜 (vegetable) = 野菜 (vegetable)

mnemonic: Human beings are essentially SWEET, although on the other hand, Pol Pot.
Rice is the essential part of nine out of ten Japanese meals!

kunyomi.meaning: stylish (present or clothes) but also a considerate or supportive person.( (KANA, JERK)

jukugo.word: 純粋 な ( じゅんすい な)
jukugo.meaning: the essence of something. Pure pleasure! Pure blood! Pure honor!
description: 純 (epitome) + 粋 (essence) = 純粋 (essence)

mnemonic: After the farmers harvest the crops, they RE-USE the grain to plant next year's crops.
Rice grains, on the tops of the rice shoots, appear to be standing up facing the sun.

kunyomi.meaning: a grain,, for instance . . . rice

jukugo.meaning: an atomic particle, as in 'particle physics.'
description: 粒 (grain) + 子 (child) = 粒子 (atomic particle.)

mnemonic: It's FUN to snort powder!
If you keep dividing rice kernels smaller and smaller, you will wind up with powder.

kunyomi.meaning: powder

jukugo.word: 花粉症 ( かふんしょう )
description: 花 (flower) + 粉 (powder) + 症 (symptom) = 花粉症 (hay fever)
小 (small size) + 麦 (barley) + 粉 (powder) = 小麦粉 (flour)

mnemonic: rice 〔米) plus a line, which we'll call a horizontal bolt of RAIghtning. So you can say . . .
In the future, we'll use RAIghtning to cook our rice! ZAP!!!!
description: This is used as a PREFIX, meaning next : (next year, month, week).HOWEVER, BOOBOO!!! It's NEVER used with tomorrow, or next hour, or next minute. Nonono. Sorry.

kunyomi.meaning: come

description: 来 (come/future) + 年 (year) = 来年 (next year)
来 (come/future) + 月 (moon) = 来月 (next month)

jukugo.word: は or が 出来る (は or が できる )
jukugo.meaning: it's possible to do.(I can run, I can shit, but I can't run and shit at the same time.) (1/2 KANA)
description: 出 (pull out / hand over) + 来 (come/future) = 出来る (possible)
以 (compared to) + 来 (come/future) = 以来 (since then)

jukugo.meaning: a specific person's future (i.e. the dumb interview question, "What do you see yourself doing 10 years from now?") Also sometimes used with Japan's future.

mnemonic: I'd like to BAN the number 13 because it is unlucky.
I'll come to your rice paddy if you write down the address NUMBER.

jukugo.meaning: number which has been assigned to a thing, as in phone number or apartment number, or ZIP code number.
description: 番 (number) + 号 (number) = 番号 (number)
一 (one) + 番 (number) = 一番 (number one!)

jukugo.meaning: police box - a small shop in your neighborhood where police hang out and wait to help you or jail you.
description: 交 (combine) + 番 (number) = 交番 (police box)

jukugo.word: XXX 番目 のYYY (XXX ばんめ のYYY)
jukugo.meaning: this is a term used in counting things in a row. For instance, in English we'd say "Second book from the right" or "Third shelf from the top" in Japanese, they'd say: 2番目のbook OR 4番目のshelf. (COUNTER, KUNKUN)
description: 番 (number) + 目 (eye) = 番目 (thing in a row)

mnemonic: The prisoner was being judged for stealing a number of SHINY crowns.

jukugo.word: 審査 する ( しんさ する)
jukugo.meaning: to judge or examine something - anything from Charles Manson's trial to American Idol. Anything with a panel of judges. Also when the fire marshal or the IRS comes to do an Official Inspection.
description: 審 (judge) + 査 (inspect) = 審査 (investigation, judging)

mnemonic: A big hippy wearing a big TIE DIED T-shirt.
This big fat hippy, legs apart, arms apart, waiting to hug you WHEN YOU LEAST EXPECT IT.
description: If you're looking up a 大　jukugo in your dictionary and can't find it, try using おお instead of 　だい or たい. For some reason, this kanji tends to go kunyomi in its jukugo!

kunyomi.meaning: big

description: 大 (big) + 好 (like) = 大好き (really like)

jukugo.word: 大変 な ( たいへん な)
jukugo.meaning: this has 2 meanings, both used equally often:
description: "Tony is tai hen!" , for instance, could mean:
a) I feel sorry for Tony because his job sucks and his girl is cheating.
b) Tony is a really scary, mean person.
大 (big) + 変 (change) = 大変 (that's terrible!)

jukugo.word: 大事 な ( だいじ な)
jukugo.meaning: vital, important. Can also be used as a sort of goodbye - but only in cases where you're sort of worried about the person. Like if they're coming down with a cold, you'd say, "お大事に！”　instead of ”またね！”
description: 大 (big) + 事 (action/ incident) = 大事 (vital)

jukugo.meaning: adult, as opposed to minor, not as opposed to 'with clothes on.' (FP)
description: 大 (big) + 人 (person) = 大人 (adult)

jukugo.word: 大家 さん ( おおや さん)
description: 大 (big) + 家 (home) = 大家 (landlord)

jukugo.word: 大型 の ( おおがた の)
description: 大 (big) + 型 (type / proper way) = 大型 (large-scale )

mnemonic: George got a big kernel of rice lodged waaay in the back of his stache , and he wants you to reach in and try to dislodge it.

kunyomi.meaning: way in the back： Back of the closet, back of the casket, back of the cave, etc.

jukugo.meaning: wife (used about my own wife as well as your wife) (literally,'back of the house person' - OH SNAAAAAP!!) (FP, FR)

mnemonic: It's possible for a KEY to be over 10 feet big, but it would be a little strange.

jukugo.word: 奇妙 な ( きみょう な)
jukugo.meaning: weird - but more broad than the related term 妙. 奇妙 means unusual and absurd - a street-person wearing a duck as a hat is 奇妙.
description: 奇 (strange) + 妙 (odd) = 奇妙 (weird)

jukugo.word: 好奇心 ( こうきしん )
description: BOOBOO: if you want to say you're curious about a specific thing, you'd use 興味　（きょうみ） instead.
好奇心 usually means "curiosity-in-general": 　you have an inquiring personality, or a gaze of curiosity on your face. You'd never say, "Oh, you play in a band? 好奇心ある！”
好 (like) + 奇 (strange) + 心 (heart) = 好奇心 (curiosity)

mnemonic: KEEP away!!', he says. 'Don't get close! '
The king don't like strange people to get close to his crown.

kunyomi.meaning: come near

jukugo.word: に 近寄る (に ちかよる )
jukugo.meaning: to get close to, to approach.(usually used in the negative, on warning signs: danger! keep out! danger! high voltage! 近寄るな!)
description: 近 (near) + 寄 (get close) = 近寄る (get close to)

jukugo.meaning: old person ('70s and up). This isn't rude per se, but if you want to dismiss or belittle what an old fart just said, this is the word you use. (NP)
description: 年 (year) + 寄 (get close) = 年寄り (old person)

mnemonic: My own SHOES are causing a big stink.

kunyomi.meaning: BOOBOO: the dictionary says 臭いand 　匂 are both used to mean におい(good smell), but that's bollocks. The truth is much less confusing: 匂い means good smell, and 臭い means bad.
stinky. To be stank.

jukugo.word: 面倒臭い ( めんどうくさい )
jukugo.meaning: annoying, a pain in the ass.
description: 面倒 (trouble, petty bullshit) + 臭 (SUFFIX meaning 'XXX and therefore dumb.' 古臭い　（ふるくさい) is one example　（so out of fashion that it is stinking) , also '田舎くさい　（いなくさい）' - meaning like 'stoopid redneck.' ) = 面倒臭い (pain in the ass)

jukugo.meaning: SUFFIX meaning 'XXX and therefore dumb.' 古臭い　（ふるくさい) is one example　（so out of fashion that it is stinking) , also '田舎くさい　（いなくさい）' - meaning like 'stoopid redneck.' (SUF)

jukugo.word: 汗臭い ( あせくさい )
jukugo.meaning: to be stank because you sweat.
description: 汗 (sweat) + 臭 (SUFFIX meaning 'XXX and therefore dumb.' 古臭い　（ふるくさい) is one example　（so out of fashion that it is stinking) , also '田舎くさい　（いなくさい）' - meaning like 'stoopid redneck.' ) = 汗臭い (to be stank because you sweat.)

mnemonic: It's FUN to get worked up at a concert.
the big turkey got all worked up running around the rice field

jukugo.word: 興奮 する ( こうふん する)
jukugo.meaning: to get all excited and freak out. to get really worked up. Not in a bad way. Like when you wet your pants after seeing n'sync.
description: 興 (interest) + 奮 (get worked up) = 興奮 (get excited)

mnemonic: KEEP the products in big boxes so they don't get damaged! They are delicate instruments! Especially violins!!

kunyomi.meaning: bowl or container-but also (rarely) capability (like, KRS ONE has more rappin' capability than Pharrel)

description: 楽 (enjoy) + 器 (instrument) = 楽器 (musical instrument)

jukugo.meaning: arms: unlike the related term 武器(ぶき）, 兵器 generally means things that are very modern and big: bazookas, missiles, rocket launchers, howitzers.
description: 兵 (soldier) + 器 (instrument) = 兵器 (arms)

jukugo.word: 器用 な ( きよう な)
jukugo.meaning: skillful, dexterous. Like a kung-fu fighter that can jump around and not get kicked, or a pianist who plays hella difficult pieces without any fucked notes. There is also an implication that the person can improvise!
description: 器 (instrument) + 用 (utilize) = 器用 (dexterous)

mnemonic: He TOTES a big thing that he can thrust in your hole! Now THAT'S a mnemonic.

kunyomi.meaning: to poke or jab, but not necessarily with a sharp object. Could be your finger.

jukugo.meaning: suddenly! Like 急に, but you can also use 突然 if you're sending someone an unexpected mail, or making a last-minute plan.
description: 突 (thrust) + 然 (nature) = 突然 (suddenly!)

jukugo.meaning: means impact (car crash) but also a conflict (India and Pakistan are on a collision course) or mental conflict (his communism conflicts with his love for the sexy CIA agent).
description: 衝 (collision) + 突 (thrust) = 衝突 (impact / conflict)

mnemonic: OH SHIT, that is a big stache.
To a certain kind of brawny man, having a big Moustache is central to his lifestyle.
That's right - I'm talking about Philosophers.

jukugo.meaning: central. Tokyo has a famous train line: 中央線、(the central line).
description: 中 (middle) + 央 (central) = 中央 (central)

mnemonic: Saying EYYYY over and over was the cool image that Fonzie projected to the world. (although inside, he was quite insecure)
The sun reflects off the center of a bald man's head.

kunyomi.meaning: I project
to be reflected, a shadow projected on the ground

description: 映 (project, reflect) + 画 (a drawing) = 映画 (movie)

jukugo.word: 映画館 ( えいがかん )
description: 映画 (movie) + 館 (big hall) = 映画館 (movie theater)

jukugo.meaning: any reflected, moving image - including images on TV or a computer screen, a shadow play, etc.
description: 映 (project, reflect) + 像 (statue / image) = 映像 (image)

mnemonic: People threw flowers at the hero as he triumphantly walked down the central road.

jukugo.word: 英会話 ( えいかいわ )
jukugo.meaning: an English conversation school where nobody learns. Also, a place for housewives to meet shameless Australians.
description: 英 (heroic) + 会話 (conversation) = 英会話 (English conversation school)

jukugo.meaning: hero of an adventure story or legend - (BOOBOO: it's different from the word for 'main character' (主人公(しゅじんこう）） which can be used in any kind of story.
description: 英 (heroic) + 雄 (male animal or hero) = 英雄 (hero)

mnemonic: KENNY gets eaten to death by a big dog (he's that red dot there!)

kunyomi.meaning: dog

description: 子 (child) + 犬 (dog) = 子犬 (puppy)

jukugo.meaning: Since it literally means 'losing dog,' you'd think that was a transliteration of the English 'underdog,' But no, it simply means loser or schlemiel. Japan doesn't really have much respect for plucky underdogs who dare to try and rise above their status.
description: 負 (lose) + 犬 (dog) = 負け犬 (loser)

mnemonic: He didn't want to lay face down because it would wrinkle his FUKU (服)
The person orders the dog to lay face down.

kunyomi.meaning: to lay face down - also means, "to keep this a secret, to hide the truth from outsiders."

jukugo.meaning: surrender - unlike the more casual 降参　（こうさん）, 降伏 is used when you, like, lose a war.
description: 降 (descend /rainfall / get out of vehicle ) + 伏 (lay face down) = 降伏 (surrender)

mnemonic: The inhabitants of the village gathered on THURSDAY (木曜= MOKUyobi) to burn the village dog which just would never shut up.

kunyomi.meaning: shut up. Usually said like DAMARE! (KANA)

jukugo.meaning: silence. (BOOBOO: not to be confused with 静か　（しずか）).　静か means a quiet place. 沈黙 is like a awkward hush that falls over the crowd when your mom's g-string fell off at the superbowl.
description: 沈 (sink) + 黙 (shut up) = 沈黙 (bad kind of silence)

jukugo.word: 黙って XXX ( だまって XXX)

mnemonic: ZEN Buddhism is in harmony with nature.
It's natural to set a dog on fire every evening

jukugo.meaning: absolutely! (usually used to emphasize the word after it. But sometimes, the word being emphasized is omitted because it's so obvious (to Japanese))
description: If you hear someone say 'Zenzen!' with no word after it, it might mean 'zenzen daijoubu,' ('Absolutely no problemo.') . . .
OR it might mean 'zen zen dame!' ('No effing way, guy!') (1/2 KANA)
全 (all) + 然 (nature) = 全然 (absolutely! )
自 (my own) + 然 (nature) = 自然 (nature)

jukugo.word: 当然 の ( とうぜん の)
jukugo.meaning: just, natural, deserved - although it's often used like 'That's obvious, isn't it?'
description: 当 (hit the target) + 然 (nature) = 当然 (natural, obvious)

mnemonic: Nature catches on fire and burns every Year (年=NEN)

kunyomi.meaning: I burn something up, I light something on fire. Intentionally!
something gets incinerated - destroyed by fire
burning with xxx (burning with passion, burning desire for revenge, consumed by hate, etc.)

jukugo.word: 可燃ゴミ ( かねんごみ )
description: 可 (possible) + 燃 (burn) = 可燃ゴミ (burnable garbage)

jukugo.word: 不燃ゴミ ( ふねんごみ )
description: 不 (un) + 燃 (burn) = 不燃ゴミ (unburnable garbage)

mnemonic: The only way fat dudes can get laid is to go to THAIland.
Let's consider the dot a schlong, for reasons which shall soon become clear)
Picture a dude who has to walk with his legs spread open wide, to accommodate the huge, fat schlong dangling there.

kunyomi.meaning: get fat
fat

jukugo.word: 太平洋 ( たいへいよう )
description: 太 (fat) + 平 (equal / level) + 洋 (Pacific Ocean / the West) = 太平洋 (the Pacific Ocean)

jukugo.meaning: traditional Japanese drums - the kind that can be up to 15 feet wide. (BOOBOO: Rock and roll drums are just called ドラム.)
description: 太 (fat) + 鼓 (drum) = 太鼓 (Japanese drums)

mnemonic: Your horse is too fat!! It's bad quality. So is your DAD!

jukugo.meaning: this has so many meanings: useless, bad, 'stop!' or just 'no way!' (KANA, KUNKUN)
description: 駄 (bad quality) + 目 (eye) = 駄目 (no way!)

jukugo.word: xxx　の 無駄 (xxx　の むだ )
jukugo.meaning: a waste of something (time, money) (1/2 KANA)
description: 無 (without) + 駄 (bad quality) = 無駄 (waste )

mnemonic: Flower (flowertop) + 央 (central) + 一 (one/line radical)
description: I got a flower from China, AKA the Middle Kingdom.

mnemonic: Genghis KHAN was not Chinese, he was Mongolian.
This water came from China, so it's Chinese!

description: 漢 (Chinese) + 字 (letter) = 漢字 (kanji)

jukugo.meaning: Usually 漢 means Chinese: it's used in a lot of obscure words ('Chinese dictionary,' 'Chinese herbal medicine,' 'Chinese classical literature,' etc.)
description: HOWEVER - aside from 漢字 - the only time 漢 is really used in daily life is here: 痴漢, meaning a guy who molests or gropes women on crowded trains.
So the literal reading is: 'sick Chinese' !WTF??? (FR, 1/2 KANA)
痴 (molester) + 漢 (Chinese) = 痴漢 (train pervert)

mnemonic: Baking NAN bread correctly is difficult.
Catching turkeys from China is difficult.

kunyomi.meaning: difficult

jukugo.word: 非難 する ( ひなん する)
jukugo.meaning: to criticize someone for no reason, just to nag at them.
description: 非 (injustice / mistake) + 難 (difficult) = 非難 (to criticize someone for no reason, just to nag at them.)

jukugo.meaning: a hardship, big trouble. Not like "Oh, If I fail this test, I'm going to be in big trouble!" こんなん is more like an ongoing hardship, like your parents died when you were young and you had to put yourself through school while working 20 hours a week washing dishes. Also often used in this phrase: 困難の時代 (troubled times) (NP)
description: 困 (trouble) + 難 (difficult) = 困難 (hardship)

mnemonic: The dudes who came from China to do be employed are hella strong and KEEN on working.

kunyomi.meaning: to be employed at xxx company (emphasis is on the physical work rather than the role). (used only about a job, and not in reference to a particular project at that job)
my duties, my job

jukugo.word: 通勤 する ( つうきん する)
description: 通 (pass) + 勤 (be employed at) = 通勤 (commute)

mnemonic: I lament that I got too TAN in Hawaii. Now I got melanomas!!
Your mouth laments that kanji came from China and now you have to learn it even though you are in Japan!

kunyomi.meaning: emit a wail of despair or mourning (1/2 KANA)

description: 驚 (astonish) + 嘆 (lament, sigh) = 驚嘆 (amazemenｔ)

mnemonic: Flower (flowertop) + 日 (sun, day) + 大 (big)
description: Opium flowers grow big in the sunSTRONG RADICAL : usually "BO."

mnemonic: MO is for MOdel.
Lou Reed carved a realistic model of an opium poppy out of a tree.

jukugo.meaning: a pattern which does not have pictures: fractals , mandala, plaid, zeebra skin. wood. do NOT use about representational patterns like flower-print or kids’ pajamas with horsies on them. 模様 also has a more formal meaning: ‘the details of an incident’ : You might hear a train/airport announcement which says "We will explain the details of the delay" ( 遅れるの模様。 ) (1/2 KANA)
description: 模 (model) + 様 (important person) = 模様 (pattern)

jukugo.meaning: a model (this is literal! Model, like a snap-tite model car or model train)
description: 模 (model) + 型 (type / proper way) = 模型 (plastic model)

jukugo.meaning: a model: Can be a person (a role model, a model sudent), or a thing (a model home, a model economy). (BOOBOO: Not model like a plastic model tank or gandam)
description: 模 (model) + 範 (standard / the best way to do) = 模範 (model - prototype)

mnemonic: Your mother went to an early grave from smokin' too much opium, so now she's buried in the earth.

kunyomi.meaning: grave

description: 墓 (grave) + 地 (area) = 墓地 (graveyard)

mnemonic: Your mother makes a living by selling opium every day!

kunyomi.meaning: This doesn't correspond to any English word. Maybe the closest phrase is, "To lead one's life."

kunyomi.word: It means "to live in a place" as well as "to do all one's daily junk (eating, sleeping, hanging out)." 暮らす is usually used in sentences like, "over 30,000 people are living in the city." or "Live on $20 a day," or "She had an easy/hard life."
途方に暮れる ( とほうにくれる )
kunyomi.meaning: to be at a loss, to feel like WTF can I do??
LOOKALIKES:
暮         make a living         DAY         日
You recruit members to give your organization more STRENGTH.

kunyomi.word: The grave is in the EARTH.
kunyomi.meaning: But you carve a model airplane out of WOOD.

mnemonic: Your mom was recruited to sell opium because she's so strong, she can keep the block locked down all by herself if need be.

kunyomi.meaning: to raise funds, solicit contributions (for a magazine ,etc.), to find workers or soldiers.

jukugo.word: 募集中 ( ぼしゅうちゅう )
jukugo.meaning: you'll see this sign a lot. It means 'now hiring!'
description: 募 (recruit) + 集 (collect) + 中 (middle) = 募集中 (now hiring)

jukugo.word: 応募 する ( おうぼ する)
description: 応 (react) + 募 (recruit) = 応募 (to apply for a job.)

mnemonic: Old MACK Donald had a farm, and on this farm he had beef curtains.
There's an opium addict hiding behind the curtain holding a dagger. When you walk by, he'll jump out and stab you, take your shit and sell it for dope.
description: literal curtains, as well as metaphorical curtains, as in 'The mafia who are controlling the city do it in secret, behind the black curtains (黒幕).'

kunyomi.meaning: literal curtains, as well as metaphorical curtains, as in 'The curtain fell on his career when he got caught humping a loaf.'

description: 字 (letter) + 幕 (curtain) = 字幕 (sub-titles)

jukugo.meaning: most people in the West called the Shogun government "feudalism", but the shoguns themselves called it BAKUFU。 (FP)
description: 幕 (curtain) + 府 (government) = 幕府 (Shogun government)

mnemonic: Welcome BACK TO the desert, motherfucker! All us scorpions and vultures missed you!
Addicts need opium like desert travelers need water.

description: 砂 (sand) + 漠 (desert) = 砂漠 (desert )

jukugo.word: 漠然とした ( ばくぜんとした )
jukugo.meaning: vague, obscure: unlike the related term 紛らわしい　（まぎらわしい）、漠然 isn't intentionally misleading - it has more the sense of a vague old memory you can't picture clearly even if you try.
description: 漠 (desert) + 然 (nature) = 漠然とした (vague)
This is different than "mouth" because you put other radicals INSIDE it. You'll get it.

mnemonic: The origin of the universe was IN a big bang, because a big amount of energy burst out of a microscopic box.

description: 原 (original/ high plain) + 因 (origin) = 原因 (cause)

mnemonic: The origin of kindness is ON the heart.

kunyomi.meaning: gratitude. Unlike the related words 恩恵　（おんけい） and 義理 (ぎり）, 恩 means that you really WANT to do something nice, to give back to the person you're grateful to. Also, unlike 義理、恩 doesn't imply that you owe them a specific favor. Often, 恩 is used like, "Everyone else gave up on me, told me I was a juvenile delinquent, that I'd amount to nothing. That teacher was the only one who believed in me, who kept encouraging me no matter how many times I fucked up. とても恩がある。"

jukugo.meaning: favor. Unlike the very personal "恩", giving and receiving 恩恵 is a more businesslike form of gratitude: 恩恵を受ける means "to recieve a favor." A sort of I'll-scratch-your-back-if-you-scratch-mine practicality.
description: 恩 (kindness) + 恵 (do a favor) = 恩恵 (favor)

jukugo.word: 恩知らず ( おんしらず )
description: 恩 (kindness) + 知 (know) = 恩知らず (ingrate)

mnemonic: Your KINfolk ain't nothing but bacteria!!
The flower planted in the box full of wheat became infected with bacteria.

description: 細 (slender) + 菌 (bacteria) = 細菌 (bacteria (regular word))

jukugo.meaning: a germ (usually used as a kids' insult - an "EWW you're gross!" kind of word) (1/2 KANA, KIDS)

mnemonic: The pine tree is in trouble- it kind of got lost all its CONES, got chopped down and turned into a big pine box.

kunyomi.meaning: to be in trouble. . . .not exactly. It doesn't mean 'punishment' like 'You're in trouble!' means in English. It's not like your teacher yelling at you. If you're late and can't find your shoes, that's こまった. If you're lost, that's こまった. If you forgot your password for ratemycheneyfanfiction.org, that's . . . actually you're better off, probably. (BOOBOO)

jukugo.meaning: a hardship, big trouble. Not like "Oh, If I fail this test, I'm going to be in big trouble!" こんなん is more like an ongoing hardship, like your parents died when you were young and you had to put yourself through school while working 20 hours a week washing dishes. Also often used in this phrase: 困難の時代 (troubled times) (NP)
description: 困 (trouble) + 難 (difficult) = 困難 (hardship)

mnemonic: A person stole some SHOES and got thrown in a big box of a cell- now he's a prisoner.

description: 囚 (prisoner) + 人 (person) = 囚人 (prisoner )

mnemonic: Imagine a small box rotating inside a big box. like, I dunno, gears or something.
Then, use the rotating gears to reel in the string for that KITE, so you don't have to do it by hand.
description: Literally, it means 'to rotate.' However, mostly you'll see it used to mean 'xxx amount of times.' I guess you could think of clock hands rotating around the clock, but it's still a JERK.

kunyomi.meaning: I roate it
It rotates

description: 今 (now) + 回 (rotate / times) = 今回 (this time)

jukugo.meaning: every time. Every single fucking time. Jesus! Get it together, man. Sometimes I don't know what goes on in your head.
description: 毎 (every) + 回 (rotate / times) = 毎回 (every time)
一 (one) + 回 (rotate / times) = 一回 (one time)

jukugo.meaning: last time (last time, this happened, last time we met). although in practice people tend to use the more irritating and ambiguous 'この 前.' (back then)
description: 前 (before) + 回 (rotate / times) = 前回 (last time)

mnemonic: That KODOMO (子) is hard to deal with.

kunyomi.meaning: Hard like a stiff, formal, tight-ass person, stubborn.
( を ) かた＊める
( が ) かた＊まる
JUKUGO:
頑 (stubborn) + 固 (hard) = 頑固 (stubborn)

description: 個 (individual) + 人 (person) = 個人 (personal)

kunyomi.meaning: ： surround.( to be surrounded： XXX に かこまれた)

kunyomi.meaning: treasure

jukugo.word: 宝くじ ( たからくじ )

description: 宝 (treasure) + 石 (rock) = 宝石 (jewel.)
